Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research fellowship awarded to Vidya Venkateswaran is "Combinatorial representation theory." The host institution for the fellowship is Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Pavel Etingof.

Performance_Institution.Name: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Department of Mathematics

POR.DRECONTENT:
Combinatorial representation theory is an exciting area of mathematics that has intersections with many other subfields (for example, number theory and physics).  The goal is to understand abstract algebraic objects through concrete combinatorial entities, which may be easier to model or enumerate.

The objectives of this project were to (1) conduct mathematical research in the area of combinatorial representation theory, (2) teach courses at a variety of different levels, (3) mentor students interested in mathematics, and (4) disseminate research through papers and talks.  While an NSF postdoctoral fellow at MIT, the PI single-authored several research papers in different topics in combinatorial representation theory.  She met regularly with her mentor to discuss ongoing research projects and received a lot of useful advice about career development.  At MIT, she taught introductory undergraduate courses such as calculus and differential equations, as well as more advanced courses such as combinatorial analysis and a topics class.  She also served as a co-organizer of MIT's combinatorics seminar.  This involved recruiting speakers from all over the country to give talks on active and exciting areas of research.  She mentored younger women interested in mathematics through a local area program.  Finally, she gave several seminar and conference talks on the research mentioned above.
